pullrequest.title: updating to new ros key using PGP block format

content.raw: Yes I found the same issue yesterday. Thanks for fixing it. The old ros key does not work. I am not sure which format is better though.
content.html: Yes I found the same issue yesterday. Thanks for fixing it. The old ros key does not work. I am not sure which format is better though.

pullrequest.title: updating to new ros key using PGP block format

content.raw:
Confirmed that [a new key came out on June 7](https://discourse.ros.org/t/new-gpg-keys-deployed-for-packages-ros-org/9454).

After some looking around, it appears that the two formats are equivalent except the text version is more convenient in many cases. I think the binary version was probably used accidentally last time. @{557058:4ded1ddf-947e-4154-bbd1-3dba24f1bdbd} can you confirm? Although the old key is only a minor inconvenience for developers who understand how keys work, it causes our installation tutorials to fail. Also, integrating this PR would avoid the need to keep a file that is out of sync with our code base while we’re testing various branches in preparation for the 1.1 release.
content.html:
Confirmed that a new key came out on June 7.

After some looking around, it appears that the two formats are equivalent except the text version is more convenient in many cases. I think the binary version was probably used accidentally last time. @Carlos Agüero can you confirm? Although the old key is only a minor inconvenience for developers who understand how keys work, it causes our installation tutorials to fail. Also, integrating this PR would avoid the need to keep a file that is out of sync with our code base while we’re testing various branches in preparation for the 1.1 release.

pullrequest.title: updating to new ros key using PGP block format

content.raw:
I made this change and it worked. Is it better practice to store the `.key` files or do something like this?

```
RUN wget -P /tmp/ http://packages.osrfoundation.org/gazebo.key
RUN wget -P /tmp/ http://packages.ros.org/ros.key
# COPY docker/keys/gazebo.key /tmp/gazebo.key
# COPY docker/keys/ros.key /tmp/ros.key
```
content.html:
I made this change and it worked. Is it better practice to store the .key files or do something like this?

RUN wget -P /tmp/ http://packages.osrfoundation.org/gazebo.key
RUN wget -P /tmp/ http://packages.ros.org/ros.key
# COPY docker/keys/gazebo.key /tmp/gazebo.key
# COPY docker/keys/ros.key /tmp/ros.key

pullrequest.title: updating to new ros key using PGP block format

content.raw:
I think the normal thing to do is to run something like:

apt-key adv --keyserver hkp://ha.pool.sks-keyservers.net:80 --recv-key <KEY\_ID>

to import the correct key. \(See the[ ROS installation instructions on the ROS wiki.](http://wiki.ros.org/melodic/Installation/Ubuntu)\). 

However, we had a problem with the keyserver being down a significant amount of the time, which causes the docker build to fail, so instead we decided to store a local copy of the key. The problem with this approach is that we need to update the key ourselves when it changes.

That said, it’s very likely that whoever made the local copy did it the way you did, since it seems that the ros.key stored there is in the binary format \(and the text version, which would also work, is called ros.asc\). Could you point me to the source of this method? My guess is that it predates the use of the key server.

Anyway, to answer your question: we could go back to fetching the key on the fly, but if we do that my opinion is that it’s a little better to use the keyserver. My preference is to keep using a local file, however, and just update it.
content.html:
I think the normal thing to do is to run something like:

apt-key adv --keyserver hkp://ha.pool.sks-keyservers.net:80 --recv-key <KEY_ID>

to import the correct key. (See the ROS installation instructions on the ROS wiki.).

However, we had a problem with the keyserver being down a significant amount of the time, which causes the docker build to fail, so instead we decided to store a local copy of the key. The problem with this approach is that we need to update the key ourselves when it changes.

That said, it’s very likely that whoever made the local copy did it the way you did, since it seems that the ros.key stored there is in the binary format (and the text version, which would also work, is called ros.asc). Could you point me to the source of this method? My guess is that it predates the use of the key server.

Anyway, to answer your question: we could go back to fetching the key on the fly, but if we do that my opinion is that it’s a little better to use the keyserver. My preference is to keep using a local file, however, and just update it.

pullrequest.title: updating to new ros key using PGP block format

content.raw: I think you’re right. Either go for the keyserver method or storing it. I didn’t know that the keyserver is down often enough to make things an issue, but if it is then we should definitely go for just storing they key as a local file.
content.html: I think you’re right. Either go for the keyserver method or storing it. I didn’t know that the keyserver is down often enough to make things an issue, but if it is then we should definitely go for just storing they key as a local file.
